verses.text: Truly my soul waits in silence for God; from Him comes my salvation.
verses.comment: The psalmist opens by emphasizing total dependence on God. The word 'salvation' here points not only to rescue but also spiritual deliverance, which will later be ultimately fulfilled in Christ (see Matt. 1:21).

verses.text: He alone is my rock and my salvation, my fortress; I will never be greatly shaken.
verses.comment: Calling God 'my rock' and 'fortress' signals unshakeable trust, themes later echoed by Jesus teaching on building one's life on solid foundation (Matt. 7:24). Salvation is depicted as personal, yet communal in the context of God's covenant people.

verses.text: How long will you attack a man, all of you, to batter him down, as if he were a leaning wall, a tottering fence?
verses.comment: The psalmist laments unjust opposition, using vivid imagery of weakness. This suffering is suggestive of the righteous being persecuted, a motif fulfilled in the life of Christ (Isa. 53:3; John 15:20).

verses.text: They only plan to cast him down from his high position; they delight in lies. With their mouths they bless, but inwardly they curse.
verses.comment: This verse draws attention to hypocrisy and hidden malice, something Jesus condemned in spiritual leaders (Matt. 23:27). Spiritual integrity is highlighted as essential for those who worship God in truth.

verses.text: My soul waits silently for God alone, for my hope is from Him.
verses.comment: Hope in God is presented as steadfast and exclusive. Waiting in silence evokes reverence, reminiscent of meditative prayer, which has deep roots in ancient Christian worship.

verses.text: He alone is my rock and my salvation, my fortress; I will not be shaken.
verses.comment: Repeats verse 2, reinforcing confidence in God's protection. The language mirrors the security found in God's covenant promises, which find their fullness in Christ (Rom. 8:38-39).

verses.text: On God rests my salvation and my glory; the rock of my strength, my refuge, is in God.
verses.comment: Salvation and spiritual 'glory' are rooted in God alone. The concept of refuge has a spiritual dimension: believers find strength and identity in God's presence, hinting at the importance of worship and spiritual union.

verses.text: Trust in Him at all times, O people; pour out your hearts before Him. God is a refuge for us.
verses.comment: Communal call to trust and heartfelt prayer is parallel to New Testament encouragement to bring every care before God (Phil. 4:6). The psalmist links individual and collective faith, a concept foundational to Christian community and worship.

verses.text: Surely men of low estate are but a breath, those of high estate are a delusion; in the scales they rise, they are altogether lighter than a breath.
verses.comment: This verse reminds us of human limitation and vanity. The transience of life is a frequent theme in wisdom literature (Eccl. 1:2). Recognizing our frailty prepares us to seek dependence on Divine grace.

verses.text: Do not trust in oppression, nor put vain hope in robbery; if riches increase, do not set your heart on them.
verses.comment: Strong warning against materialism and injustice. Similar teaching is found in Jesus' sermon on the mount. True Christian discipleship involves detachment from wealth and setting our heart on God.

verses.text: God has spoken once; twice have I heard this: power belongs to God.
verses.comment: The 'once...twice' formula stresses certainty and emphasis in Hebrew thought. God's omnipotence is declared, foreshadowing New Testament revelation of Christ's divine authority (Matt. 28:18).

verses.text: And to You, Lord, belongs steadfast love; for You reward each one according to his work.
verses.comment: God's steadfast love ('hesed') and just judgment are foundational. The idea that God rewards according to works prepares believers for New Testament teachings on judgment and the importance of living faith demonstrated through actions (James 2:24).
